column1: Leiden (
column2: Dutch: [ˈlɛi̯də(n)] (listen); in English and archaic Dutch also Leyden) is a city and municipality in the province of South Holland
column3: Netherlands. The municipality of Leiden had a population of 123
column4: 856 in August 2017
column5: but the city forms one densely connected agglomeration with its suburbs Oegstgeest
column8: 647 inhabitants. The Netherlands Central Bureau of Statistics (CBS) further includes Katwijk in the agglomeration which makes the total population of the Leiden urban agglomeration 270
column10: and in the larger Leiden urban area also Teylingen
column12: and Noordwijkerhout are included with in total 348
column13: 868 inhabitants. Leiden is located on the Oude Rijn
column14: at a distance of some 20 kilometres (12 miles) from The Hague to its south and some 40 km (25 mi) from Amsterdam to its north. The recreational area of the Kaag Lakes (Kagerplassen) lies just to the northeast of Leiden.

column1: A university city since 1575
column2: Leiden has been one of Europe's most prominent scientific centres for more than four centuries. Leiden is a typical university city
column3: university buildings are scattered throughout the city and the many students from all over the world give the city a bustling
column4: vivid and international atmosphere. Many important scientific discoveries have been made here
column5: giving rise to Leiden's motto: ‘City of Discoveries’. The city houses Leiden University
column6: the oldest university of the Netherlands
column7: and Leiden University Medical Center. Leiden University is one of Europe's top universities
column8: with thirteen Nobel Prize winners. It is a member of the League of European Research Universities and positioned highly in all international academic rankings. It is twinned with Oxford
column9: the location of the United Kingdom's oldest university. Leiden University and Leiden University of Applied Sciences (Leidse Hogeschool) together have around 35
column10: 000 students. Modern scientific medical research and teaching started in the early 18th century in Leiden with Boerhaave.

column1: Leiden is a city with a rich cultural heritage
column2: not only in science
column3: but also in the arts. One of the world's most famous painters
column4: Rembrandt
column5: was born and educated in Leiden. Other famous Leiden painters include Lucas van Leyden
column6: Jan van Goyen and Jan Steen.

column1: == History ==
Leiden was formed on an artificial hill (today called the Burcht van Leiden) at the confluence of the rivers Oude and Nieuwe Rijn (Old and New Rhine). In the oldest reference to this
column2: from circa 860
column3: the settlement was called Leithon. The name is said to be from Germanic *leitha- "canal"  in dative pluralis
column4: thus meaning "at the canals". "Canal" is actually not the completely proper word. A leitha (later "lede") was a human-modified natural river

column1: Leiden has in the past erroneously been associated with the Roman outpost Lugdunum Batavorum. This particular castellum was thought to be located at the Burcht of Leiden
column2: and the city's name was thought to be derived from the Latin name Lugdunum. However the castellum was in fact closer to the town of Katwijk
column3: whereas the Roman settlement near modern-day Leiden was called Matilo.

column1: The landlord of Leiden
column2: situated in a stronghold on the hill (motte)
column3: was initially subject to the Bishop of Utrecht but around 1100 the burgraves became subject to the county of Holland. This county got its name in 1101 from a domain near the stronghold: Holtland or Holland.

column1: Leiden was sacked in 1047 by Emperor Henry III. Early 13th century
column2: Ada
column3: Countess of Holland took refuge here when she was fighting in a civil war against her uncle
column4: William I
column5: Count of Holland. He besieged the stronghold and captured Ada.

column1: Leiden received city rights in 1266. In 1389
column2: its population had grown to about 4
column3: 000 persons.

column1: === Siege of 1420 ===

column2: during the Hook and Cod wars
column3: Duke John III of Bavaria along with his army marched from Gouda in the direction of Leiden in order to conquer the city since Leiden did not pay the new Count of Holland Jacqueline
column4: Countess of Hainaut
column5: his niece and only daughter of Count William VI of Holland.

column1: Burgrave Filips of Wassenaar and the other local noblemen of the Hook faction assumed that the duke would besiege Leiden first and send small units out to conquer the surrounding citadels. But John of Bavaria chose to attack the citadels first.

He rolled the cannons along with his army but one which was too heavy went by ship. By firing at the walls and gates with iron balls the citadels fell one by one. Within a week John of Bavaria conquered the castles of Poelgeest
column2: Ter Does
column3: Hoichmade
column4: de Zijl

column1: On 24 June the army appeared before the walls of Leiden. On 17 August 1420
column2: after a two-month siege the city surrendered to John of Bavaria. The burgrave Filips of Wassenaar was stripped of his offices and rights and lived out his last years in captivity.

column1: === 16th to 18th centuries ===
Leiden flourished in the 16th and 17th century. At the close of the 15th century the weaving establishments (mainly broadcloth) of Leiden were very important. After the expulsion of the Spaniards
column2: Leiden cloth
column3: Leiden baize and Leiden camlet were familiar terms. In the same period
column4: Leiden developed an important printing and publishing industry. The influential printer Christoffel Plantijn lived there at one time. One of his pupils was Lodewijk Elzevir (1547–1617)
column5: who established the largest bookshop and printing works in Leiden
column6: a business continued by his descendants through 1712 and the name subsequently adopted (in a variant spelling) by contemporary publisher Elsevier.In 1572
column7: the city sided with the Dutch revolt against Spanish rule and played an important role in the Eighty Years' War. Besieged from May until October 1574 by the Spanish
column8: Leiden was relieved by the cutting of the dikes
column9: thus enabling ships to carry provisions to the inhabitants of the flooded town. As a reward for the heroic defence of the previous year
column10: the University of Leiden was founded by William I of Orange in 1575. Yearly on 3 October
column11: the end of the siege is still celebrated in Leiden. Tradition tells that the citizens were offered the choice between a university and a certain exemption from taxes and chose the university. The siege is notable also for being the first instance in Europe of the issuance of paper money
column12: with paper taken from prayer books being stamped using coin dies when silver ran out.Leiden is also known as the place where the Pilgrims (as well as some of the first settlers of New Amsterdam) lived (and operated a printing press) for a time in the early 17th century before their departure to Massachusetts and New Amsterdam in the New World.In the 17th century
column14: in part because of the impetus to the textile industry by refugees from Flanders. While the city had lost about a third of its 15
column18: and may have come near to 70
column19: 000 circa 1670. During the Dutch Golden Era
column20: Leiden was the second largest city of Holland
column21: after Amsterdam. Particularly due to the work by Herman Boerhaave (1668–1738)
column22: it played a crucial role in the establishment of modern chemistry and medicine.

column1: From the late 17th century onwards Leiden slumped
column2: mainly due to the decline of the cloth industries. In the beginning of the 19th century the baize manufacture was altogether given up
column3: although industry remained central to Leiden economy. This decline is painted vividly by the fall in population. The population of Leiden had sunk to 30
column4: 000 between 1796 and 1811
column6: 044. From the 17th to the early 19th century
column7: Leiden was the publishing place of one of the most important contemporary journals
column9: known also as Gazette de Leyde.

column1: === 19th and 20th centuries ===
On 12 January 1807
column2: a catastrophe struck the city when a boat loaded with 17
column3: 400 kilograms (38
column4: 360 pounds) of gunpowder blew up in the middle of Leiden. 151 persons were killed
column6: 000 were injured and some 220 homes were destroyed. King Louis Bonaparte personally visited the city to provide assistance to the victims. Although located in the centre of the city
column7: the area destroyed remained empty for many years. In 1886 the space was turned into a public park
column9: the railroad from Leiden to Haarlem was inaugurated and one year later the railway to Den Haag was completed
column10: resulting in some social and economic improvement. Perhaps the most important piece of Dutch history contributed by Leiden was the Constitution of the Netherlands. Johan Rudolf Thorbecke (1798–1872) wrote the Dutch Constitution in April 1848 in his house at Garenmarkt 9 in Leiden.

column1: Leiden's reputation as the "city of books" continued through the 19th century with the establishment of publishing dynasties by Evert Jan Brill and Albertus Willem Sijthoff. Sijthoff
column2: who rose to prominence in the trade of translated books
column3: wrote a letter in 1899 to Queen Wilhelmina regarding his opposition to becoming a signatory to the Berne Convention for the Protection of Literary and Artistic Works. He felt that international copyright restrictions would stifle the Dutch publishing industry.

column1: Leiden began to expand beyond its 17th-century moats around 1896 and the number of citizens surpassed 50
column3: new industries were established in the city
column4: such as the canning and metal industries. During World War II
column5: Leiden was hit hard by Allied bombardments. The areas surrounding the railway station and Marewijk were almost completely destroyed.

column1: === Leiden today ===

The city's biggest and most popular annual festival is celebrated at 3 October and is called simply 3 Oktober. The people of Leiden celebrate the end of the Spanish siege of 1574. It typically takes place over the course of two to three days (usually two but three if there's a Sunday involved) and includes parades
column2: a hutspot feast
column3: historical reenactments
column4: a funfair and other events. The city has recently started to host the Leiden International Film Festival
column5: the fastest growing festival of its type in the Netherlands.Leiden has important functions as a shopping and trade centre for communities around the city. The University of Leiden is famous for its many discoveries including Snells law (by Willebrord Snellius)

column1: the famous Leyden jar
column2: a capacitor made from a glass jar
column3: invented in Leiden by Pieter van Musschenbroek in 1746.  Another development was in cryogenics: Heike Kamerlingh Onnes (1913 Nobel prize winner in physics) liquefied helium for the first time (1908) and later managed to reach a temperature of less than one degree above the absolute minimum. Albert Einstein also spent some time at Leiden University during his early to middle career.

column1: The city also houses the Eurotransplant
column2: the international organization responsible for the mediation and allocation of organ donation procedures in Austria
column3: Belgium
column4: Croatia
column7: the Netherlands and Slovenia.  Leiden also houses the headquarters of Airbus
column8: a global pan-European aerospace and defence corporation and a leading defence and military contractor worldwide. The group includes Airbus
column9: the leading manufacturer of commercial aircraft worldwide.

column1: == Rivers
column2: canals and parks ==

column1: The two branches of the Oude Rijn
column2: which enter Leiden on the east
column3: unite in the centre of the city. The city is further intersected by numerous small canals with tree-bordered quays. On the west side of the city
column4: the Hortus Botanicus and other gardens extend along the old Singel
column5: or outer canal. The Leidse Hout park
column6: which contains a small deer park
column7: lies on the northwest border with Oegstgeest. The Van der Werf Park is named after the mayor Pieter Adriaansz. van der Werff
column8: who defended the city against the Spaniards in 1574. The city was beleaguered for months and many died from famine. The open space for the park was formed by the accidental explosion of a ship loaded with gunpowder in 1807
column10: including that of the Elsevier family of printers.

column1: == Buildings of interest ==
Because of the economic decline from the end of the 17th until the middle of the 19th century
column2: much of the 16th- and 17th-century city centre is still intact. It is the second largest 17th-century town centre in the Netherlands
column3: the largest being Amsterdam's city centre.

column1: A hundred buildings in the centre are decorated with large murals of poetry
column2: part of a wall poem project active from 1992
column3: and still ongoing.

column1: === Fortifications ===
At the strategically important junction of the two arms of the Oude Rijn stands the old castle de Burcht
column2: a circular tower built on an earthen mound. The mound probably was a refuge against high water before a small wooden fortress was built on top of it in the 11th century. The citadel is a so-called motte-and-bailey castle. Of Leiden's old city gates only two are left
column3: the Zijlpoort and the Morspoort
column4: both dating from the end of the 17th century. Apart from one small watch tower on the Singel nothing is left of the town's city walls. Another former fortification is the Gravensteen. Built as a fortress in the 13th century it has since served as house
column5: library and prison. Presently it is one of the University's buildings.

column1: === Churches ===
The chief of Leiden's numerous churches are the Hooglandse Kerk (or the church of St Pancras
column2: built in the 15th century and containing a monument to Pieter Adriaansz. van der Werff) and the Pieterskerk (church of St Peter (1315)) with monuments to Scaliger
column3: Boerhaave and other famous scholars. From a historical perspective the Marekerk is interesting too. Arent van 's Gravesande designed that church in 1639. Other fine examples of his work in Leiden are in the Stedelijk Museum De Lakenhal (the municipal museum of fine arts)
column4: and the Bibliotheca Thysiana. The growing city needed another church and the Marekerk was the first Protestant church to be built in Leiden (and in Holland) after the Reformation. It is an example of Dutch Classicism. In the drawings by Van 's Gravesande the pulpit is the centrepiece of the church. The pulpit is modelled after the one in the Nieuwe Kerk at Haarlem (designed by Jacob van Campen). The building was first used in 1650
column5: and is still in use. The Heilige Lodewijkkerk is first catholic church in Leiden that was built after the Reformation. This church was given to the Catholics after the gunpowder explosion in 1807
column6: which killed 150 inhabitants and destroyed a large part of the city centre. The 'Waalse Kerk' (Breestraat 63) was originally part of the Katharina Hospital. In 1584 it became the church of Protestant refugees from the Southern Netherlands (Brugge) and France. Later churches in the centre include the St. Joseph in expressionistic style.

column1: === University buildings ===

The city centre contains many buildings that are in use by the University of Leiden. The Academy Building is housed in a former 16th-century convent. Among the institutions connected with the university are the national institution for East Indian languages
column2: ethnology and geography; the botanical gardens
column3: founded in 1587; the observatory (1860); the museum of antiquities (Rijksmuseum van Oudheden); and the ethnographical museum
column4: of which P. F. von Siebold's Japanese collection was the nucleus (Rijksmuseum voor Volkenkunde). This collection is now housed in a separate museum called the SieboldHuis. The Bibliotheca Thysiana occupies an old Renaissance building of the year 1655. It is especially rich in legal works and vernacular chronicles. Noteworthy are also the many special collections at Leiden University Library among which those of the Society of Dutch Literature (1766) and the collection of casts and engravings. In recent years the university has built the Leiden Bio Science Park at the city's outskirts to accommodate the Science departments.

== Miscellaneous ==
The coat of arms of Leiden is two red keys
column2: crossed in an X-shape on a white background. These keys are the Keys of Heaven held by St. Peter
column3: for whom a large church in the city centre is named. Because of this coat of arms
column4: Leiden is referred to as the "Sleutelstad" ("the key city").

column1: For a time Leiden held the title "The Coldest Place on Earth" because of the developments in cryogenics in a laboratory there. Heike Kamerlingh Onnes (1913 Nobel prize winner in physics) liquefied helium for the first time (1908)
column2: and later managed to reach a temperature of less than one degree above Absolute zero.

column1: The Norwegian cheese "nøkkelost" ("key cheese") is named after the keys in coat of arms of Leyden
column2: as it is a variation of Leyden cheese.

column1: Factor V Leiden is named after the city of Leiden where it was discovered in 1994.
The Leyden jar
column2: a capacitor made from a glass jar
column3: was invented here by Pieter van Musschenbroek in 1746. It was actually first invented by Ewald Georg von Kleist the year before
column4: but the name "Leyden jar" stuck.

column1: Leiden's Stadhuis (Town Hall) has a poem in the form of a cryptogram on its façade that records the date 1574 in Roman numerals
column2: the year of the "Black Famine" or Spanish siege (W equals two Vs):

column1: (Dutch: "When the Black Famine had brought to the death nearly six thousand persons
column2: then God the Lord repented
column3: and gave bread again as much as we could wish".)

column1: == Sports ==
Zorg en Zekerheid Leiden is the basketball club of Leiden. In 2011 and 2013 they won the National Title
column2: in 2010 and 2012 the National Cup and in 2011 and 2012 the National Super Cup. The club also played in the FIBA EuroChallenge and reached the Second Round (Best 16) in 2011/2012.
